title: Cross-Site Request Forgery
overview: <paragraph>In the majority of today's web applications, clients are required to submit forms which can perform sensitive operations.<paragraph></paragraph>An example of such a form being used would be when an administrator wishes to create a new user for the application.<paragraph></paragraph>In the simplest version of the form, the administrator would fill-in:<paragraph></paragraph>* Name * Password * Role (level of access)<paragraph></paragraph>Continuing with this example, Cross Site Request Forgery (CSRF) would occur when the administrator is tricked into clicking on a link, which if logged into the application, would automatically submit the form without any further interaction.<paragraph></paragraph>Cyber-criminals will look for sites where sensitive functions are performed in this manner and then craft malicious requests that will be used against clients via a social engineering attack.<paragraph></paragraph>There are 3 things that are required for a CSRF attack to occur:<paragraph></paragraph>1. The form must perform some sort of sensitive action. 2. The victim (the administrator the example above) must have an active session. 3. Most importantly, all parameter values must be **known** or **guessable**.<paragraph></paragraph>The tool discovered that all parameters within the form were known or predictable and therefore the form could be vulnerable to CSRF.<paragraph></paragraph>_Manual verification may be required to check whether the submission will then perform a sensitive action, such as reset a password, modify user profiles, post content on a forum, etc._</paragraph>
remediation: <paragraph>Based on the risk (determined by manual verification) of whether the form submission performs a sensitive action, the addition of anti-CSRF tokens may be required.<paragraph></paragraph>These tokens can be configured in such a way that each session generates a new anti-CSRF token or such that each individual request requires a new token.<paragraph></paragraph>It is important that the server track and maintain the status of each token (in order to reject requests accompanied by invalid ones) and therefore prevent cyber-criminals from knowing, guessing or reusing them.<paragraph></paragraph>_For examples of framework specific remediation options, please refer to the references._</paragraph>
